Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Optoelectronic neural scaffolds: materials platform for investigation and control of neuronal activity and development

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1253890
Anikeeva

Intellectual Merit

This CAREER proposal aims to bridge the gap between advanced optoelectronic
materials design and invasive and outdated devices used to treat neurological
disorders. By developing flexible, biocompatible polymer-based optoelectronic scaffolds
(OPTELS) a strategy for incorporating individual optically sensitive neurons into neural
recording and stimulation devices will be created. These trapped neurons will be
investigated as relays of optical stimulation or inhibition to intact neural networks, which
will potentially enable future clinical applications of optogenetics, a powerful optical
neural stimulation tool, without genetic modification of the patient. Specifically the
project will be focused on the following objectives: (1) Developing fiber-inspired
fabrication methods for hollow-core polymer-based OPTELS and employing them to
isolate key materials parameters (surface geometry, charge, flexibility) contributing to
survival and growth of electronically active neurons; (2) Using OPTELS to investigate
and control neuronal growth with the goal of axonal guidance along the OPTELS core.
The proposed study will explore chemical, optoelectronic and mechanical stimuli and
employ OPTELS ability to record and stimulate neural activity to determine factors
contributing to axonal growth; (3) Employing neurons trapped in OPTELS cores as relay
devices of optical neural interrogation. Genetic modification will be applied to the
neurons trapped within the OPTELS cores to enable expression of light-sensitive ion
channels - opsins. The controlled formation of synapses between these relay neurons
and the outside networks will be applied to the investigation of optogenetic interrogation
of the network without directly genetically modifying it.

Broader Impact

The proposed project will explore materials interfaces between optoelectronic devices
and neural tissues providing a pathway towards intimate physiological neuroprosthetic
devices for treatment of debilitating neurological conditions such as Parkinson's disease
or spinal cord injury. The educational and outreach components of the project are
designed to enhance materials engineering and optoelectronics education at MIT and at
inner city community colleges through classroom training and hands-on laboratory
internships. Specifically the outreach program aims to increase awareness about the
impact of engineering in medicine among community college students and teachers
through the seminar series "Medical Electronics and Optics: Life-saving Engineering",
and 10-week research and education summer internships in the PIs laboratory. In
addition new lecture material and device-design based assignments will be developed
for the core undergraduate course on optical and electronic materials and a graduate
photonics course will be adapted to senior undergraduates with the goal of advancing
optoelectronics knowledge among the students. The educational materials will be made
available to worldwide community of learners through an open MIT web-based
resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project was motivated by the limited regenerative ability of the neural tissue and the need for tools to repair severed nerves following injury. To understand the biological and physical factors contributing to the nerve growth in synthetic guidance scaffolds, we combined fiber fabrication methods and optical neural stimulation techniques. Fiber fabrication is commonly used in production of optical telecommunication cables and is typically applied to glasses. During this process, a macroscopic model, a preform, is heated and drawn into a kilometer long fiber with microscopic features and cross sectional geometry precisely matching that of the preform. This process can be applied to a variety of materials including polymers, composites, and metals as long as all elements within a preform exhibit similar viscosity at the fiber drawing conditions. This versatility was leveraged in our research, allowing for the development of nerve guidance scaffolds with a diversity of geometries. Using these thermally drawn scaffolds we were able to identify the structural elements contributing to directionality and speed of nerve growth.

In addition to scaffold engineering our project took advantage of optogenetics – a method that employs microbial light-sensitive ion channels, opsins, to impart sensitivity to visible light onto mammalian neurons. This decade-old technique permits on-demand inhibition and excitation of neuronal activity. In our project, we applied this technique to demonstrate that neuronal excitation contributes to improved growth. Furthermore, we identified optimal stimulation parameters that maximized nerve extension.

Finally, we have applied fiber-drawing techniques to create devices capable not only of optical stimulation of neural activity but also of simultaneous recording and drug delivery into the brain and spinal cord. Using our fiber-based probes implanted in the spinal cord we were able to optically control and electrically record muscle movement. Furthermore, our fiber-based probes were able to deliver opsin genes into the nervous system, and then monitor the onset of light sensitivity through recording of neural activity during optical stimulation. We anticipate that our findings will benefit basic study of the nervous system and will offer insights into the treatments of the traumatic nerve and spinal cord injuries. All research publications resulting from this CAREER project are freely available through the DSpace engine (http://dspace.mit.edu) supported by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

In addition to fundamental and applied research, this project has contributed to educational initiatives. We have initiated a vibrant internship program for students and faculty from the Roxbury and Bunker Hill Community Colleges, who spent summers in our laboratory. All of our community college student trainees have gone onto four-year colleges and some are already pursuing graduate degrees in engineering and science. Finally, the project has supported a revision of an undergraduate subject (3.024 “Electronic, Optical, and Magnetic Properties of Materials”), which is also now available in an open on-line format (mitx-3-024x) through the MIT and Harvard EdX platform (https://www.edx.org).
